ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Ableton/DAW
An understanding of EDM in historical and practical terms. The course enhanced my skills with Ableton and basic music theory.
I enjoyed learning about musical lingo and techniques
We learned about some of the main genres of EDM, common rhythmic patterns used, and the history/development of electronic instruments, as well as how to use certain effects on Ableton.
I learned to use AbletonLive, learned new frameworks for analyzing electronic music, and got to know a lot of the history behind the technologies and techniques that helped develop the genre.
I learned a great deal about music theory, music production, sound synthesis, and using commercial music production software.
I learned the fundamentals of EDM and how to work with Ableton software.
I gained a lot of familiarity with different types of EDM, different historical and modern tools for making EDM, types of rhythms and melodies, and some basic music theory.

This course assisted in the understanding of the fundamentals of music theory and increased my overall interest in producing, mixing, and sampling music. I had little to zero knowledge in music theory but now I can count a songs time signature by just listening to a song, I understand different parts of a song like a build-up, beat drop, etc. I want to further these interest in my next couple of years at Yale.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Dr. A is a huge strength of this course as she is both engaging and understanding.
Absolutely no complaints. I loved how there were different options for the final project. Only wish I had taken the class during the school year, five weeks went by too quickly.

This course was extremely well-planned and well-taught.  I think the AbletonLive demonstrations were somewhat useful, but probably could have been done by us students on our own time - the course was great overall and could have benefitted from more history of the genres discussed (the cultural context in which they developed, influences on each genre from outside of EDM would have been really cool - I've been reading up on this since the course ended and enjoyed it a lot)

I really like the breadth of topics the course covered. I wish there was more theory about overall song structure and composition. I would have also loved to see more class projects/presentations. Working on my own music productions was the most fun part of the class and where I learned the most.

I think the course assignments are very clear and understandable.

I wish there was more participation.

Strengths: The subject matter is interesting and fun. Getting the opportunity to make a song or to analyze one of your favorite tracks for a final project is super unique compared to my other courses. Professor Alexander also really cares about student learning and is willing to spend extra time to make sure you are understanding everything.

Weaknesses: The majority of the assignments felt like busy work. Most of them were fill-in-the-blank that were 1-to-1 with lecture notes (I suppose to make sure you saw what was covered in lecture) which felt a bit silly to me.

Strengths of the course include the dummied down version of explaining music theory. The course made no assumptions on the levels of exposure to music theory and truly taught the course from the bottom up. Focusing on broader topics in the beginning of the course and as the course developed it slowly focused into the finer details of music theory. 
Weakness of the course include equipment available for even further understanding. There are many types of equipment that will be required when practically applying the knowledge in the studio, equipment that is standard and would help bring everything together especially for newbies like myself. 
If the course had any type of hybrid aspect like classes being taught online for the academic portion and then in person at one of the many recording studios on campus, that would be extremely beneficial.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Learn abt EDM and also practice producing music. I highly recommend trying to make an original tune for the final project.
I would recommend this course to students interested in a low-stakes introduction to EDM, music theory, and Ableton.

I highly recommend this course! The material is engaging and homework assignments were straightforward. It's assumed that most people who take the class have no experience with music, so there are lectures dedicated to basic music theory. And by the end you'll be able to make some music using a DAW which is very cool.
Absolutely.  The course is really accessible to musicians and non-musicians alike, and there's so much to learn about a genre of music that's so popular today.
Absolutely. Anyone who has a modicum of interest in music theory, music production, or modern EDM music in general should take this course.
For students looking to learn the basics of Ableton, I would recommend it.

For sure. This course was not particularly challenging (probably the easiest I've taken at Yale) and it was pretty fun. I got to show my friends the EDM track I made for my final project and they were impressed.

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: I will better appreciate music and find more detailed ways to analyze it.
Hopefully I'll be composing some pieces in the future!
Hopefully quite a bit - I saved down the slides from the course, and will hopefully be composing more EDM in the future
For independent music production projects
This course--especially the final project--made me really enjoy making electronic music and I may pick up the hobby for the future.

Ableton training is required for access to the recording studios on campus and now that I'm properly trained, I will live in the recording studio in my residential college. The goal is to make songs casually by producing a beat, collaborating with students for vocals, and making songs that can be enjoyed by the entire student body. Yale is a liberal arts college and i want to make producing your own music a culture at Yale.
